questions.text: A patient presents with acute onset of double vision, difficulty walking, and confusion. Given a history of alcohol abuse, what is the most appropriate initial treatment? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intravenous thiamine

 

The patient presents with a triad of symptoms: Ophthalmoplegia (double vision due to paralysis of eye muscles), Ataxia (difficulty walking), and Global confusion (Mnemonic: GOA). These symptoms are characteristic of Wernicke's encephalopathy, a serious condition often associated with chronic alcohol abuse. Wernicke's encephalopathy is caused by a deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1). The most appropriate initial treatment is the administration of intravenous thiamine, which is crucial to prevent progression and potential irreversible damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intravenous fluids with dextrose: Administering dextrose without prior thiamine can exacerbate Wernicke's encephalopathy, as it can precipitate the onset of symptoms in individuals with thiamine deficiency. This makes it an inappropriate initial treatment.

 

Option C. Intravenous lorazepam: Lorazepam is used to manage alcohol withdrawal symptoms such as seizures and agitation but is not indicated in the acute management of Wernicke's encephalopathy. It does not address the underlying thiamine deficiency.

 

Option D. Intravenous vitamin B12: While vitamin B12 deficiency can cause neurological symptoms, it is not associated with Wernicke's encephalopathy. Thiamine is the specific treatment required in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wernicke's encephalopathy, characterized by the triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and confusion, should be treated immediately with intravenous thiamine to prevent serious neurological damage.

questions.text: Which of the following is measured by the device shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oxygen saturation

 

  • Oxygen saturation (often referred to as SpO2) is the percentage of oxygen-saturated hemoglobin relative to the total hemoglobin (unsaturated + saturated) in the blood.
  • The device measures this by non-invasively detecting the color change in blood as it binds oxygen.
  • The image displays a reading of "98%", which is consistent with an SpO2 reading. Thus, this option is correct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oxygen content of the blood:

 

  • This refers to the amount of oxygen bound to hemoglobin in the blood plus any oxygen dissolved directly in the blood.
  • Pulse oximeters do not measure the total oxygen content of the blood. They only measure the percentage of oxygen-saturated hemoglobin.

 

Option C. Partial pressure of oxygen:

 

  • Partial pressure of oxygen (often referred to as PaO2) is the pressure exerted by oxygen in the blood. It's typically measured using an arterial blood gas analysis.
  • Pulse oximeters do not measure PaO2.

 

Option D. Amount of inspired oxygen:

 

  • This refers to the concentration of oxygen that a person is inhaling, often given as a percentage or fraction (FiO2).
  • Pulse oximeters do not measure the amount of inspired oxygen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pulse oximetry measures the oxygen saturation (SpO2) of hemoglobin in the blood using the principles of Beer Lambertâ€™s law and plethysmography.

questions.text: All of the following structure pass through the aortic opening of diaphragm except? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Vagal trunk

 

The vagal trunk does not pass through the aortic opening of the diaphragm.

 

It passes through the esophageal opening at the level of T10 vertebra.

 

The vagal trunks refer to the vagus nerves, specifically the right and left vagus nerves (cranial nerves X). These nerves are responsible for various functions in the body, including regulating heart rate, gastrointestinal activity, and respiratory functions. While the vagus nerves do extend into the thoracic cavity, they do not pass through the aortic opening of the diaphragm. Instead, they enter the abdomen separately.

 

 

 

The aortic opening of the diaphragm is an anatomical structure that allows certain structures to pass between the thoracic and abdominal cavities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aorta: It passes through the aortic opening of the diaphragm as it descends from the thoracic cavity (descending aorta) into the abdominal cavity (abdominal aorta). This is a significant passage, as it allows the aorta to continue its course into the abdomen.

 

Option B. Azygous Vein: It drains blood from the posterior thoracic and abdominal walls. It ascends through the aortic opening of the diaphragm to enter the superior vena cava. This allows for the return of blood from the posterior part of the body to the superior vena cava and then into the right atrium of the heart.

 

Option C. Thoracic Duct: It is responsible for draining lymph from the lower half of the body and the left upper half of the body. It also passes through the aortic opening of the diaphragm to enter the thoracic cavity and eventually drain into the venous circulation.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Alcohol abuse is strongly associated with the development of: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dilated cardiomyopathy

 

Alcohol abuse is strongly associated with the development of dilated cardiomyopathy.

 

Alcohol and its metabolites, acetaldehyde, have a toxic effect on the myocardium which leads to the development of dilated cardiomyopathy.

 

 

Dilated cardiomyopathy causes include:

 

Acquisition of causes

 

  • The most frequent causes of myocarditis worldwide are infectious (particularly coxsackievirus B) and non-infectious myocarditis.
  • In India, alcohol is the most frequent culprit.
  • Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PCM) and pregnancy-associated cardiomyopathy (PACM) (PPCM)
  • Takotsubo cardiomyopathy brought on by stress

 

Meth-related:

 

  • Doxycycline (anthracycline)
  • Cyclophosphamide and trastuzumab

 

A lack of nutrition:

 

  • Carnitine deficiency; Keshan disease (selenium); Beriberi (thiamine);
  • Endocrine: acromegaly, diabetes mellitus, hypo- and hyperthyroidism
  • Additional
  • Toxicity of cobalt, Heavy metals (lead, mercury, arsenic, lithium)

 

Genetic factors (50%):

 

Haemochromatosis; Duchenne muscular dystrophy; Becker's muscular dystrophy; cardiac myocyte titin gene mutation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pericarditis: While alcohol can have widespread effects on the body, it is not directly associated with the development of pericarditis.

 

Option B. Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy: This condition involves the thickening of the heart muscle, primarily due to genetic causes, and is not directly linked to alcohol use.

 

Option D. Myocarditis: Generally caused by infections (particularly viral), autoimmune disorders, or toxic exposures, but not specifically by alcohol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dilated cardiomyopathy associated with alcohol abuse reflects the cumulative detrimental effects of alcohol on heart structure and function, compounded by nutritional deficiencies and genetic factors, making it a critical concern in chronic alcohol consumers.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female patient presented with a history of pathological fracture of the neck of femur. On lab investigations, ALP and N-telopeptide levels were raised. The DEXA scan confirmed the diagnosis as osteoporosis. Based on the lab values of osteoporosis, which other values will be raised in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tartrate Resistant Acid Phosphatase

 

In osteoporosis, there is an imbalance between bone resorption (breakdown) and bone formation, with resorption exceeding formation. This leads to bone weakening, which is why the patient has a pathological fracture.

 

The key markers that are elevated in cases of osteoporosis include N & C terminal telopeptides and tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP), which are markers of increased bone resorption. In osteoporosis, TRAP levels are elevated, indicating that bone destruction is occurring at a higher rate than formation.

 

Other markers like ALP (alkaline phosphatase) may also be raised, but the specific marker for bone resorption and the correct answer in this case is TRAP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alanine Transaminase: This is a liver enzyme commonly elevated in liver diseases, but it has no direct association with bone metabolism or osteoporosis.

 

Option B. Aspartate Aminotransferase: Like ALT, AST is another liver enzyme, primarily elevated in liver damage and certain heart conditions. It is unrelated to bone resorption or osteoporosis.

 

Option C. Lactate Dehydrogenase: LDH is an enzyme found in many tissues and may be elevated in conditions involving tissue breakdown, but it is not specific to bone resorption or osteoporosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) is elevated in osteoporosis due to increased bone resorption, making it a key marker for this condition.

questions.text: Which of the following investigations is shown in the radiograph? ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Barium meal

 

Explanation:

 

The given image is a barium meal. This study is used to examine the stomach and proximal duodenum.

 

Visual Cues: The image shows the distribution of barium within the stomach, outlining its contours and revealing its internal structure, which is typical in a barium meal examination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Barium Swallow: This study primarily evaluates the esophagus and does not extend into the stomach. The radiograph showing the stomach filled with barium indicates that the procedure goes beyond just a barium swallow.

 

Option C. Barium Meal Follow Through: This investigation involves not only the stomach but also a sequential imaging of the small intestine as the barium passes through. The specific image provided does not show barium beyond the proximal duodenum, which is typical in a simple barium meal.

 

Option D. Barium Enema: This procedure is used to visualize the large intestine (colon) and rectum using barium introduced via the rectum. The provided image showing the stomach filled with barium clearly indicates that it's not a barium enema.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Skin, Subcutaneous tissue, Superficial fascia and Deep fascia
Skin, Subcutaneous tissue, Superficial fascia, Deep fascia and a few muscular fibers

questions.text: Identify the correct order of layers incised while performing a fasciotomy for compartment syndrome? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Skin, Subcutaneous tissue, Superficial fascia and Deep fascia

 

The incision for a fasciotomy involves the skin, subcutaneous tissue, superficial fascia, and deep fascia.

 

  • Deep fascia is a dense connective tissue layer that surrounds muscles, bones, and neurovascular structures. It creates the compartments in limbs, and in compartment syndrome, it is this fascial layer that is primarily responsible for the elevated pressures.
  • For a fasciotomy, the incision goes through the skin, subcutaneous tissue, superficial fascia, and, crucially, the deep fascia. This releases the increased pressure in the muscle compartment and restores blood flow.
  • The procedure is best carried out via longitudinal incisions of skin, subcutaneous fat, and superficial and deep fascia.
  • The lower limb can be decompressed via two incisions, each being lateral to the subcutaneous border of the tibia.
  • This gives access to the two posterior compartments and to the peroneal and anterior compartments of the leg.

 

 

Educational Objective:


During a fasciotomy for compartment syndrome, the incision must pass through the skin, subcutaneous tissue, superficial fascia, and deep fascia to adequately decompress the affected muscle compartments.

choices.text: Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy

questions.text: An octogenarian female comes to your clinic reporting feelings of constant fatigue. Upon performing imaging studies, you discover that she has a scleroatrophic gallbladder containing impacted stones. In addition, a sizable stone is detected within the common bile duct, causing dilation of the biliary tree. What should be the subsequent course of action in her treatment? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography

 

Explanation:

 

Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure that allows for the visualization and management of bile duct stones. It is particularly useful when there is a stone in the common bile duct (CBD). ERCP can be used to remove or extract stones from the common bile duct and may also involve the placement of a stent to relieve biliary obstruction if necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy: Cholecystectomy (removal of the gallbladder) may be considered as a subsequent procedure, but it is usually not the initial step in patients with impacted stones in the gallbladder and CBD stones. ERCP is performed first to address the CBD stone and relieve any associated biliary obstruction.

 

Option C. Wait and watch: Waiting and watching may not be appropriate in this case because the patient is symptomatic with constant fatigue, which can be related to biliary obstruction. Immediate intervention is necessary to relieve the obstruction and prevent complications.

 

Option D. CT scan: A CT scan may have been done as part of the initial imaging studies to assess the condition, but it is not the definitive treatment for gallbladder and CBD stones. The primary treatment should focus on relieving the obstruction caused by the CBD stone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is the preferred initial treatment for patients with common bile duct stones and biliary obstruction, as it allows for both diagnosis and therapeutic intervention, such as stone removal and stent placement.

questions.text: Criteria for FRU include all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 24-hour MTP facility

 

Explanation:

 

The criteria for a functional First Referral Unit (FRU) include:

 

  1. 24-hour delivery services
  2. Emergency obstetric care, including surgical intervention (implying surgical intervention is a criterion)
  3. Blood storage facility
  4. RTI/STI management
  5. Newborn care
  6. Care of sick children
  7. Full range of family planning services, including safe abortion services (but not explicitly 24-hour MTP facility)
  8. Essential laboratory services
  9. Transport facility

 

The criteria "not included" for an FRU is the availability of a 24-hour MTP (Medical Termination of Pregnancy) facility. It states that while 24-hour delivery services are available, a 24-hour MTP facility is not explicitly listed as a criterion for an FRU.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a functional First Referral Unit (FRU), the criteria include 24-hour delivery services, emergency obstetric care (including surgical intervention), blood storage facility, RTI/STI management, newborn care, care of sick children, family planning services, essential laboratory services, and transport facility. However, the availability of a 24-hour MTP (Medical Termination of Pregnancy) facility is not explicitly a criterion for an FRU.

questions.text: Where chemical waste can be disposed? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Yellow

 

Chemical waste is disposed of in yellow-colored containers.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the most common chemistry of gallstones among the following options? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Crystalline cholesterol monohydrate

 

Explanation:

 

Gallstones are crystalline formations that occur in the gallbladder due to the precipitation of substances found in bile. The most common type of gallstones are cholesterol stones, which account for about 80% of all gallstone cases. These stones primarily consist of crystalline cholesterol monohydrate.

 

Types of Gallstones:

 

  • Cholesterol Stones: These are the most prevalent type, made primarily of crystalline cholesterol monohydrate. They are often yellow-green and can vary in size from small grains to large stones.
  • Pigment Stones: Comprising about 20% of gallstones, pigment stones are made of bilirubin and can be either black or brown. These are more likely to form in individuals with liver disease or hemolytic disorders.
  • Mixed Stones: These stones contain both cholesterol and pigment components, and may also include calcium bilirubinate, which is a part of some pigment stones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Crystalline cholesterol dihydrate: This is not a common form of gallstones. Cholesterol stones typically form in the monohydrate crystalline structure rather than dihydrate.

 

Option C. Amorphous cholesterol dihydrate: Gallstones are rarely composed of amorphous cholesterol, and the dihydrate form is not typical. The monohydrate crystalline form is the most common.

 

Option D. Amorphous cholesterol monohydrate: Gallstones are generally crystalline in nature rather than amorphous. Crystalline cholesterol monohydrate is the most common form found in gallstones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common chemistry of gallstones is crystalline cholesterol monohydrate, which constitutes about 80% of all gallstone cases.

questions.text: All are the members of the medical board in MTP > 24 weeks, except? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Legal advisor

 

For medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) after 24 weeks, especially in cases of substantial fetal anomalies, a medical board is constituted. This board typically includes specialists relevant to the condition and the required medical care. The standard members include: Radiologist, Gynecologist and Pediatrician.

 

A legal advisor is not a part of this medical board, as the board's purpose is to provide medical, not legal, expertise. The fourth member is often a specialist relevant to the detected anomaly rather than a legal professional.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiologist: Included to assess fetal abnormalities through imaging and provide critical information about the anomaly.

 

Option B. Gynecologist: A core member who handles the MTP procedure and provides obstetric and gynecological care.

 

Option D. Pediatrician: Included to give an opinion on the implications of fetal anomalies and expected postnatal outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In MTP cases beyond 24 weeks, the medical board consists of medical professionals such as radiologists, gynecologists, and pediatricians, but not legal advisors.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl is brought to the hospital by her mother. She  complaints of pain in the abdomen. On examination her UPT is positive. What will be first step done by  you as a medical officer :
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inform police

 

In many jurisdictions, pregnancy in a minor may be considered evidence of statutory rape or sexual abuse, hence, informing the police is crucial for legal proceedings and safeguarding the minor.

 

Other Options

 

 

Educational objective :

 

When dealing with potentially criminal situations involving minors, such as a young teenager's pregnancy, the first step is to ensure the situation is addressed legally and safely. Informing law enforcement and ensuring proper medical and legal procedures safeguard the minor's health and legal rights.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male, employed as a welder, presents with the following eye symptoms: pain, redness, and excessive tearing. What would be the appropriate next step in managing this condition?(FMGE Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Remove with 26G needle

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of foreign body in the eye. Removal of the foreign body using a 26G needle is the next step in the management of this patient.

 

  • Foreign bodies must be removed as soon as possible.
  • The removal technique depends on the location and nature of the foreign body.
    1. Lying loose in the lower fornix: Evert the lower lid and remove with a clean swab.
    2. The upper lid (sulcus subtarsalis): Evert and double evert with a Desmarres retractor, if required then remove with a clean swab. In case of difficulty, anaesthetize the conjunctival sac.
    3. Embedded in the bulbar conjunctiva: Remove with a foreign body spud or fine forceps under topical anaesthesia. A disposable sterile hypodermic needle may also be used.
    4. The cornea: Remove using the slit lamp or operating microscope. Anaesthetize the eye and hold the lids apart with the first and second fingers of your left hand, pressing slightly backwards so as to steady the globe.
  • First attempt to remove the foreign body by dislodging it with a sterilized spud.
  • If repeated efforts fail, a disposable hypodermic (26 or 27 gauge) needle should be used.
  • The greatest care should be taken not to scrape the epithelium more than is absolutely necessary.
  • In all cases: an antibiotic ointment should be applied and the eye kept bandaged for a day.
  • Particles of stone show a greater tendency than metal to cause infective ulceration, probably because metallic particles are often hot and therefore sterile when they enter the eye.
  • Occasionally, sharp steel and other particles penetrate deep into the cornea without perforating it. The efforts made to remove them may push them deeper or even into the anterior chamber. Special precautions should be taken if such a scenario is suspected.
  • If the particle is magnetizable, magnetic removal should be tried, but it is usually necessary to incise the cornea overlying the foreign body. However, this method may fail, particularly if the particle is small and in case the particle enters the AC, it has to be removed by other methods.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syringing and washing: This is not typically used for embedded foreign bodies and is more appropriate for chemical injuries or superficial debris.

 

Option B. Antibiotics and steroids: While antibiotics are used post-removal to prevent infection, steroids are not the primary treatment for foreign body removal.

 

Option C. Keratoplasty: This is a surgical procedure for corneal transplants and is not indicated for foreign body removal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appropriate management of a corneal foreign body, especially in an occupational setting like welding, involves careful removal using a sterile hypodermic needle, followed by the application of antibiotic ointment to prevent infection.

questions.text: A patient suffered burns following which the surgical procedure was done as shown in the image. Which of the following best describes the likely procedure done? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thiersch skin graft

 

The image shows a meshed graft, which is characteristic of a Thiersch skin graft, also known as a split-thickness skin graft (STSG). This type of graft involves taking a thin layer of skin from a donor site, which includes the epidermis and part of the dermis. The meshing process creates perforations in the graft, increasing its surface area and allowing exudates to escape, which facilitates healing. Meshing also helps the graft to cover a larger area, which is particularly useful in cases of extensive burns.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Full thickness skin graft: This involves transplanting the entire thickness of the skin (epidermis and entire dermis). These grafts are typically used for areas requiring better cosmetic outcomes, such as the face, and are not usually meshed.

 

Option C. Biological mesh: This is used in various surgical repairs, such as hernias, and involves biological material to reinforce or replace tissue. It is not typically used for skin grafting in burns.

 

Option D. Artificial membrane: This refers to synthetic or biologically engineered membranes used to cover wounds or burns. The image shows a skin graft rather than an artificial membrane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A meshed appearance on a graft used for burn treatment indicates a Thiersch skin graft (split-thickness skin graft), which is designed to cover a larger area and facilitate exudate drainage.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image given below: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Fornix

 

  • The image given shows a midsagittal section of the brain.
  • The structure marked is the Fornix.
  • The fornix is a C-shaped bundle of white matter located in the medial surface of the brain, just below the corpus callosum.
  • The fornix is an important part of the limbic system, and it is the hippocampus's largest single pathway, connecting it to various subcortical structures.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pineal gland: It is a small endocrine gland located in a midsagittal section, seen as a small structure located posterior to the third ventricle in the midline, projecting from the diencephalon. Its main hormone, melatonin, plays a critical role in the regulation of circadian rhythms, influencing sleep-wake cycles.

 

Option B. Falx cerebri: It is a dural fold that descends vertically in the longitudinal fissure, which divides the cerebral hemispheres. In a midsagittal view, it appears as a thin membrane running vertically between the left and right cerebral hemispheres. The falx cerebri attaches anteriorly to the crista galli of the ethmoid bone and posteriorly to the internal occipital protuberance.

 

Option D. Pituitary gland: It is often referred to as the "master gland", is an endocrine gland responsible for producing several critical hormones that regulate growth, blood pressure, and other functions. In the midsagittal view, the pituitary gland is located at the base of the brain, hanging down from a stalk (infundibulum) from the hypothalamus. This gland rests within a depression in the sphenoid bone called the sella turcica.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fornix is a C-shaped bundle of nerve fibers that acts as a major output tract from the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies and then onto the thalamus. In the midsagittal section, the fornix is seen as an arching structure that lies inferior to the corpus callosum, the massive fiber tract connecting the two cerebral hemispheres. The body of the fornix travels anteriorly and inferiorly, eventually dividing into left and right columns which curve downward in front of the thalamus.

choices.text: Telomere stability is associated with aging
Abnormal telomerase activation is associated with aging
Decreased telomere length is associated with aging
Increased telomere length is associated with aging

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding the telomerase theory of aging? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreased telomere length is associated with aging.

 

  • Telomeres are short, TG-rich repeated DNA sequences found at the ends of linear eukaryotic chromosomes. Telomeres do not contain any protein coding sequences. They are necessary for the complete replication of chromosome ends as well as the protection of the ends from fusion and degradation.
  • Telomeres at the ends of chromosomes are normally shortened with each cell division. Cell-cycle arrest or apoptosis may result if telomeres are shortened beyond a certain point. This is referred to as replicative senescence.
  • Telomerase is an enzyme that prevents telomeres from shortening. It is a specialized RNA-protein complex that adds nucleotides to the ends of chromosomes by using its own RNA as a template.
  • This enzyme is found in germ cells but not in most somatic cells. As a result, the majority of somatic cells age, their telomeres shorten, and they exit the cell cycle, rendering them unable to generate new cells to replace damaged cells.
  • In somatic cells, abnormal telomerase reactivation causes senescence and apoptosis. It allows the cells to divide more than usual.
  • Telomerase is usually reactivated in stem cells and cancer cells, and telomere length is stabilized, allowing the cells to proliferate indefinitely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decreased telomere length is associated with aging. Telomeres shorten with each cell division, leading to cell-cycle arrest or apoptosis when they become critically short, contributing to the aging process. Telomerase helps prevent this shortening but is typically inactive in most somatic cells, leading to aging and limited cell division capability.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of cervical erosion and spotting since 2 months. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  LBC + HPV + cervical biopsy


The patient is a 45-year-old woman presenting with cervical erosion and spotting, which raises a concern for potential cervical cancer. In such cases, the next best step involves a comprehensive approach to screen for cervical cancer:

 

  1. Liquid-based cytology (LBC): This test is used to detect abnormal cells in the cervix.
  2. HPV testing: This helps identify high-risk human papillomavirus strains that are associated with cervical cancer.
  3. Cervical biopsy: If any abnormalities are found on cytology or HPV testing, a cervical biopsy can confirm the diagnosis.

 

Performing all three tests together provides a thorough evaluation, as cervical cancer screening is essential in women presenting with these symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pap smear + HCV: While a Pap smear is appropriate for screening, HCV (Hepatitis C Virus) testing is unrelated to the current presentation of cervical symptoms.

 

Option C. Pap smear + HBV: Similar to option B, the Pap smear is correct, but testing for HBV (Hepatitis B Virus) does not address the concern for cervical cancer.

 

Option D. VDRL + HBV: VDRL is used for syphilis screening and is not relevant to cervical erosion and spotting, nor is HBV testing in this context.

 

Educational Objective:


For a patient with cervical erosion and spotting, the best approach is to screen for cervical cancer with LBC, HPV testing, and a cervical biopsy if indicated.

choices.text: ER+, PR+, HER2- High Ki67
ER+, PR+, HER2- Low Ki67
ER+, PR+, HER2+ High Ki67
ER-, PR-, HER2- High Ki67

questions.text: A patient has been diagnosed with Luminal A type of breast carcinoma. Which of the following best describes the marker profile in her? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ER+, PR+, HER2- Low Ki67

 

  • Luminal A breast carcinoma is characterized by hormone receptor positivity and low proliferation rates. The expression profile typically includes estrogen receptor positive (ER+), progesterone receptor positive (PR+), and human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 negative (HER2-). Additionally, this subtype is marked by a low Ki67 index, indicating a lower proliferation rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ER+, PR+, HER2- High Ki67: This combination, while similar in hormone receptor status, features a high Ki67 index, suggestive of a more aggressive subtype like Luminal B cancer.

 

Option C. ER+, PR+, HER2+ High Ki67: This profile describes a HER2-positive and high-proliferation subtype (often seen in more aggressive breast cancers).

 

Option D. ER-, PR-, HER2- High Ki67: Known as triple-negative breast cancer, this profile is markedly different from Luminal A as it lacks expression of ER, PR, and HER2, and is associated with higher grade tumors.

 

Educational objective:

 

Luminal A breast carcinoma is characterized by positive hormone receptors (ER and PR), absence of HER2 expression, and low Ki67 levels, indicative of a slower-growing, less aggressive tumor that typically has a better prognosis compared to other subtypes.

questions.text: The X-ray of a 5-year-old child is given below. Clinical examination, and hematological and urinary tests were normal. Which of the following is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Langerhans cell histiocytosis

 

  • The history and the provided imaging, which shows a single punched-out lytic lesion without a sclerotic rim and with a beveled edge look, point to Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH).
  • LCH is a rare disorder involving clonal proliferation of Langerhans cells, abnormal cells deriving from bone marrow and capable of migrating from skin to lymph nodes. This condition particularly affects children and can present with single or multiple lytic bone lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multiple myeloma:  A diagnosis of multiple myeloma is made by the typical triad of symptoms, which includes a marrow plasmacytosis of more than 10%, radiologic evidence of lytic bone lesions, and the presence of serum and/or urine M component.

 

 

Option C. Metastasis: In children, metastatic lesions in the skull are uncommon and typically originate from primary neuroblastoma or sarcoma but would present with different clinical features and possibly multiple lesions.


Option D. Primary hyperparathyroidism:  Patients with this condition have high levels of the parathyroid hormone, as well as hypercalcemia, hypophosphatemia, and hypercalciuria.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Langerhans cell histiocytosis is the most probable diagnosis given the age of the child, the radiographic appearance of the skull lesion, and the absence of systemic symptoms or biochemical abnormalities typically associated with the other conditions listed.

questions.text: Match the following:(INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

 

Explanation:

 

The correct matching of the procedures with their respective characteristics is as follows:

 

  • Amniocentesis (A-4): This procedure involves the assessment of amniotic fluid, often for detecting alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and other genetic conditions. It is generally performed between 15-18 weeks but may be done later as well.
  • Chorionic Villous Sampling (B-1): CVS is performed earlier in pregnancy, typically between 10-13 weeks. It involves sampling of placental tissue to test for chromosomal abnormalities and genetic conditions.
  • Fetal Blood Sampling (C-2): Also known as cordocentesis or percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (PUBS), this procedure is done around 19-20 weeks to obtain fetal blood, often for testing fetal anemia, infections, or genetic conditions.
  • Fetoscopy (D-3): This procedure involves visualizing the fetus directly in utero and is used in specific circumstances to assess fetal anatomy and perform interventions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A-4, B-3, C-2, D-1: Incorrect because Chorionic Villous Sampling (CVS) is not done at 19-20 weeks, and fetoscopy does not typically involve amniotic fluid assessment.

 

Option B. A-2, B-3, C-1, D-4: Incorrect because Amniocentesis is not done at 19-20 weeks, and fetal blood sampling is not done at 8-12 weeks.

 

Option D. A-3, B-2, C-4, D-1: Incorrect because Amniocentesis is not used to visualize fetal organs, and Chorionic Villous Sampling is not done at 19-20 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the appropriate timing and purpose of various prenatal diagnostic procedures such as Amniocentesis, Chorionic Villous Sampling, Fetal Blood Sampling, and Fetoscopy.

 

Ref: Williamâ€™s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 882, Duttaâ€™s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 741

choices.text: Variation in cell size and shape
Replacement of one type of cell by other

questions.text: Anaplasia refers to: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lack of differentiation

 

A lack of differentiation is referred to as anaplasia.

 

Anaplasia means "backward formation," implying a reversal of differentiation to a more primitive level.

 

As a result of anaplasia, morphological and functional changes in the neoplastic cells are observed like:

 

  • Loss of polarity
  • Pleomorphism - variation in the size and shape of cells
  • Increased N: C ratio (nucleus: cytoplasmic ratio) - around 1:5 in normal cells, increases to 1:1 in malignant cells
  • Hyperchromasia - coarsely clumped and darkly stained chromatin within irregular nuclei
  • Nucleolar changes - prominent nucleolus or nucleoli in the nucleus reflecting increased nucleoprotein synthesis
  • Increased mitosis - atypical, bizarre mitotic figures
  • Tumour giant cells
  • Functional (Cytoplasmic) changes

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Variation in cell size and shape: This is a feature of pleomorphism, a characteristic of anaplasia but not the definition of it.

 

Option C. Replacement of one type of cell by another: This describes metaplasia.

 

Option D. Disordered arrangement of tumor cells: This can be a feature seen in anaplastic tumors but is not definitive for anaplasia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anaplasia indicates a high grade of malignancy due to the significant loss of differentiation and structural and functional changes in the neoplastic cells.

choices.text: Ask him to bear less weight on that leg and use plaster casts

questions.text: A 57-year-old person completed his treatment of leprosy. Two years later, he presents with a punched-out painless ulcer on his sole. What is the next best step in the management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ask him to bear less weight on that leg and use plaster casts

 

The patient is presenting with a chronic trophic ulcer, which is a common complication in patients with leprosy, particularly after the disease has been treated and the bacteria eradicated.

 

Trophic ulcers arise due to the loss of sensation (neuropathy) and autonomic disturbances leading to dry, cracked skin that is prone to injury. The patient does not feel pain, which allows the ulcer to become large and deep over time.

 

The correct management involves reducing pressure on the affected area to allow healing. This can be achieved by advising the patient to bear less weight on the affected foot and using a plaster cast or a total contact cast, which redistributes weight and protects the ulcer from further trauma.

 

 

Note –

 

  • Plantar ulceration is a common complication in lepromatous leprosy, often occurring even after the disease is arrested. Progressive fibrosis of nerves leads to 'glove and stocking' anesthesia, with loss of sensation in the limbs, particularly the plantar aspect of the foot.
  • This condition is one of the most frequent impairments in leprosy, reported in 21% to 63% of newly reported cases. The combination of loss of touch and pain, along with foot deformity, causes disproportionate weight distribution on the sole of the foot, leading to non-healing or chronic ulceration.
  • Types:
    • Acute ulcers: Present with acute infection and severe acute inflammation.
    • Chronic ulcers: Long-standing ulcers without signs of acute inflammation.
    • Complicated chronic ulcers: These ulcers result from the spread of infection to deeper structures like the underlying bone, joint, or tendon sheath.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Restart MDT: Multi-drug therapy (MDT) for leprosy is used to treat active infections caused by Mycobacterium leprae. However, in this case, the patient has completed treatment, and the ulcer is due to neuropathy, not an active infection. Therefore, restarting MDT is not necessary and would not address the ulcer.

 

Option C. Aggressive Debridement with IV antibiotics: Aggressive debridement and IV antibiotics are typically indicated for infected ulcers or those with acute signs of inflammation. In this case, the ulcer is chronic and not primarily due to infection, so this approach is not warranted.

 

Option D. Amputation: Amputation is a last resort, reserved for cases where ulcers have led to severe, life-threatening complications such as osteomyelitis that cannot be managed by other means. This is not the case here, and such an extreme measure is not necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of chronic trophic ulcers in leprosy, reducing pressure on the ulcerated area through weight redistribution, such as with a plaster cast, is essential to promote healing and prevent further complication

choices.text: Fundus and body of Gall bladder

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an anterior relation of the third part of the duodenum? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Fundus and body of Gall bladder

 

Explanation:

 

The fundus and body of the gallbladder are not typically considered anterior relations of the third part of the duodenum. The gallbladder is situated more to the right and superior to the duodenum, so it is not directly in front of it.

 

Note - The junction of the first and second parts of the duodenum lies posterior to the neck of the gallbladder. The anterior relations of the third segment of the duodenum comprise the Superior mesenteric vessels, the Root of the mesentery, and Loops of the jejunum

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Superior mesenteric vessels: The superior mesenteric vessels, which include the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) and superior mesenteric vein (SMV), are anterior relations of the third part of the duodenum. The SMA runs just posterior to the third part of the duodenum, and the SMV is typically located to the right of the SMA and also in front of the duodenum.

 

Option B) Loops of jejunum:  Loops of the jejunum, which are part of the small intestine, can lie anterior to the third part of the duodenum. The small intestine, including the jejunum, is positioned in the abdominal cavity, and its loops can be found in close proximity to the duodenum.

 

Option C) Root of mesentery: The root of the mesentery is an extension of the peritoneum that connects the small intestine (including the jejunum and ileum) to the posterior abdominal wall. It passes in front of the third part of the duodenum as it continues to the jejunum and ileum. Therefore, it is an anterior relation of the third part of the duodenum.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The blood pressure of a population was tracked from childhood to adulthood. It was observed that those who had lower BP in childhood had low BP in adulthood, while those who had higher BP in childhood had high BP in adulthood. This can be best described as [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Tracking of blood pressure

 

The phenomenon described in the question is known as tracking of blood pressure. This term refers to the tendency for individuals to maintain their relative position within a distribution of blood pressure values over time. Essentially, individuals with lower blood pressure in childhood tend to have lower blood pressure in adulthood, and those with higher blood pressure in childhood tend to have higher blood pressure in adulthood.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rule of halves: This concept refers to the observation that about half of those with hypertension are aware of their condition, half of those aware are treated, and half of those treated are adequately controlled. It is not directly related to the tracking phenomenon described.

 

 

Option C. The WHO STEPwise approach: approach to surveillance (STEPS) is an internationally comparable, standardized and integrated surveillance tool through which countries can collect, analyse and disseminate core information on noncommunicable diseases (NCDs).

 

Option D. Primordial approach: Primordial prevention refers to measures taken to prevent the development of risk factors in a population, thereby reducing the overall incidence of disease. This concept is related to preventing the onset of risk factors and diseases, rather than tracking existing conditions over time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tracking of blood pressure describes the observation that individuals maintain their relative position within a distribution of blood pressure values from childhood to adulthood. This means that blood pressure levels tend to remain consistent relative to peers over time.

questions.text: The disruption of which of the following is responsible for watery diarrhea in cholera caused by Vibrio? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Zonula occludens

 

When cholera toxin is released from the bacteria in the infected intestine, it binds to the intestinal cells known as enterocytes through the interaction of the pentameric B subunit of the toxin with the GM1 ganglioside receptor on the intestinal cell, triggering endocytosis of the toxin.

 

Next, the A/B cholera toxin must undergo cleavage of the A1 domain from the A2 domain in order for A1 to become an active enzyme.

 

Once inside the enterocyte, the enzymatic A1 fragment of the toxin A subunit enters the cytosol, where it activates the G protein Gsa through an ADP-ribosylation reaction that acts to lock the G protein in its GTP-bound form, thereby continually stimulating adenylate cyclase to produce cAMP. 

 

The high cAMP levels activate the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR), causing a dramatic efflux of ions and water from infected enterocytes, leading to watery diarrhea.

 

 

The effects of cholera involve the actions of other Vibrio cholerae toxins that aid the pathogen in its colonization, coordinated expression of virulence factors, and toxin action.

 

These additional proteins include

 

  • Zona occludens toxin (zot, involved in Vibrio cholerae invasion by acting to decrease intestinal tissue resistance)
  • Accessory cholera toxin (ace, increases fluid secretion)
  • Toxin-coregulated pilus (tcpA, essential colonisation factor receptor for the CTXf phage)
  • NAG-specific heat-labile toxin (st)
  • Outer membrane porin proteins (ompU and ompT).
  • The expression of virulence factors is controlled by the transcriptional factors ToxR, TcpP and ToxT.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intercalated discs: Found in cardiac muscle cells and involved in cell-to-cell adhesion and electrical coupling, not related to intestinal fluid secretion.

 

Option B. Macula densa: Involved in regulating kidney function and blood pressure, not related to intestinal fluid secretion.

 

Option D. Hemidesmosomes: Involved in cell-to-extracellular matrix adhesion, not related to intestinal fluid secretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The disruption of zonula occludens (tight junctions) by cholera toxin is responsible for the increased permeability of intestinal epithelial cells, leading to the characteristic watery diarrhea seen in cholera.

questions.text: Drug contraindicated in asthma in PPH (Postpartum Hemorrhage) case? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carboprost

 

Carboprost is a prostaglandin F2 alpha analog that is commonly used to manage atonic postpartum hemorrhage by inducing strong uterine contractions. However, it is contraindicated in patients with asthma because it can cause bronchoconstriction and exacerbate asthma symptoms.

 

Carboprost is also contraindicated in patients with cardiac arrhythmias due to its potent cardiovascular effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methyl ergometrine: This drug is used for the management of postpartum hemorrhage due to its uterotonic properties, but it does not specifically affect asthma and is not contraindicated in asthmatic patients.

 

Option C. Misoprostol: Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 analog, is also used in postpartum hemorrhage for uterine contraction. It does not have the same bronchoconstrictive effects as Carboprost and is not contraindicated in asthma.

 

Option D. Oxytocin: Oxytocin is a common uterotonic agent used in postpartum hemorrhage management. It has no known bronchoconstrictive properties and is safe for use in asthmatic patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carboprost (PGF2 alpha) is contraindicated in patients with asthma due to its bronchoconstrictive effects.

questions.text: A patient presented with strong upper limb pulses and weak lower limb pulses with chest x-ray showing rib notching. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coarctation of Aorta

 

The classic presentation of coarctation of the aorta, a congenital condition characterized by the narrowing of the aorta. This narrowing typically occurs just after the arteries that branch off to the upper body, leading to a disparity in blood flow and pressure between the upper and lower parts of the body.

 

Key indicators in this case include:

 

  1. Strong upper limb pulses and weak lower limb pulses: The narrowing restricts blood flow to the lower extremities, causing the upper body to receive a higher volume of blood, which results in stronger pulses in the upper limbs compared to the lower limbs.
  2. Chest x-ray showing rib notching: Rib notching is a result of enlarged intercostal arteries that form collateral pathways to bypass the narrowed aorta. These arteries erode the underside of the ribs over time, creating a notched appearance on chest x-rays.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transposition of great vessels: This condition involves the switching of the major arteries (the aorta and the pulmonary artery) from their normal positions. It does not present with rib notching or a difference in pulse strength between the upper and lower limbs.

 

Option C. Tetralogy of Fallot: This is a combination of four heart defects, including a ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, and an overriding aorta. It primarily presents with cyanosis and does not typically involve rib notching or differential limb pulses.

 

Option D. Ebsteinâ€™s anomaly: This is a rare heart defect affecting the tricuspid valve and right ventricle. It does not cause rib notching or a significant difference in pulse strength between upper and lower limbs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coarctation of the aorta is identified by the presence of strong upper limb pulses, weak lower limb pulses, and rib notching on a chest x-ray, which is caused by collateral circulation developing around the narrowed section of the aorta.

questions.text: Third part of vertebral artery is related to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 2

 

The third part of the vertebral artery (V3) is related to the area marked 2, which is the posterior arch of the first cervical vertebra or the atlas.

 

The given image shows the first cervical vertebra - atlas.

 

  • The area marked 1 is the posterior tubercle.
  • The area marked 2 is the posterior arch. The superior surface bears a groove for the of vertebral artery and venous plexus immediately behind.
  • The area marked 3 is the superior articular facet.
  • The area marked 4 is the posterior surface of the anterior arch. It gives attachment to the apex of dens from the second cervical vertebra.

 

The vertebral artery is formed by the first segment of the subclavian artery. It enters the cranium through the foramina of the transverse processes of the cervical vertebrae from C6 to C1. The basilar artery is formed by the union of the vertebral arteries on both sides. In its course. it is divided into four parts:

 

  1. The first part, V1: begins at its origin from the subclavian artery and ends at its entry into the transverse process of the C6 cervical vertebra. This part is crossed by the inferior thyroid artery on both sides, and thoracic duct on the left side, and the right lymphatic duct on the right side.
  2. The second part, V2: is that part of the artery ascending through the foramina in the transverse process of the cervical vertebrae.
  3. The third part, V3: is curved backward behind the atlas. In this position, it lies in a groove on the posterior arch of the atlas. This part of the artery lies in the suboccipital triangle.
  4. The fourth part, V4: pierces the dura and arachnoid mater and unites with the contralateral vertebral artery to form the midline basilar artery at the lower border of pons.

choices.text: Medial cutaneous nerve of arm
Medial cutaneous nerve of forearm

questions.text: A patient experiences chest pain radiating to the arm. Which nerve can be responsible for the radiating pain? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intercostobrachial nerve

 

The intercostobrachial nerve is responsible for the sensory innervation of the skin of the upper medial aspect of the arm and also partially the chest wall. It is a branch of the second intercostal nerve (T2) and often gets involved in referred pain during conditions like myocardial infarction. The radiating pain from the chest to the arm, particularly in the case of heart attacks, is due to the involvement of the intercostobrachial nerve. This nerve shares dermatomes with the T1-T2 spinal segments, which also receive cardiac sensory fibers, leading to the referred pain in the arm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Musculocutaneous nerve: This nerve primarily innervates the muscles in the anterior compartment of the arm and provides sensory innervation to the lateral forearm, not typically associated with chest pain radiating to the arm.

 

Option C. Medial cutaneous nerve of arm: This nerve supplies the skin on the medial side of the arm but does not typically carry pain from the chest. It's not usually involved in referred cardiac pain.

 

Option D. Medial cutaneous nerve of forearm: This nerve supplies the skin on the medial side of the forearm and is also not typically involved in radiating chest pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The intercostobrachial nerve, originating from T2, is responsible for the sensation in the upper medial arm and can be involved in referred pain from the chest, such as during a myocardial infarction. This nerve is key in understanding the dermatome distribution related to cardiac pain.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency department in an unconscious state. The patient is dehydrated and the blood pressure of the patient is 90/60 mm Hg. Laboratory investigations revealed the serum potassium level of 6.0 mEq/L, sodium level of 129 mEq/L, and blood glucose level of 40 mg/dL. The patient has a history of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) for which he was prescribed medication by a local physician; however, the patient abruptly discontinued the medication a few weeks ago. Based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings, which of the following drugs should be administered as a life-saving measure to treat this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydrocortisone

 

Hydrocortisone is indicated as it would treat adrenal insufficiency. It would help to correct hypotension, hyperkalemia, hyponatremia, and hypoglycemia by replacing the deficient cortisol.

 

The clinical presentation of hypotension, hyperkalemia, hyponatremia, dehydration, and hypoglycemia in a patient who has suddenly stopped taking medication for RA (potentially a corticosteroid) suggests the possibility of adrenal insufficiency or Addisonian crisis. This is particularly likely if the medication the patient was taking for RA was a corticosteroid, which is common in the management of RA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sodium bicarbonate: Sodium bicarbonate is used to treat metabolic acidosis, which is not indicated in this case as there is no mention of acidosis in the given scenario.

 

Option C. Insulin: Insulin is used in the treatment of hyperkalemia to drive potassium into cells, but it would not address the underlying adrenal insufficiency and could potentially worsen the hypoglycemia.

 

Option D. Hypertonic saline: Hypertonic saline is used to treat severe hyponatremia, which is not present in this case, as the sodium level is within normal limits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrocortisone is the drug of choice for treating adrenal insufficiency or Addisonian crisis, which can present with hypotension, hyperkalemia, hyponatremia, dehydration, and hypoglycemia, especially in patients with a history of corticosteroid use who abruptly discontinue their medication.

questions.text: What concentration of fluoride is typically associated with causing crippling fluorosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) > 10 mg/L.

 

Fluoride is an element that, in appropriate concentrations, can prevent dental caries, but excessive intake can lead to various forms of fluorosis. The concentration of fluoride in drinking water (0.5-0.8 ppm or mg/L) is a key determinant of its effects on health.

 

  • Dental fluorosis typically occurs when the fluoride concentration exceeds 1.5 mg/L.
  • Skeletal fluorosis may develop when the concentration of fluoride in drinking water is between 3 to 6 mg/L.
  • Crippling fluorosis, the most severe form of fluorosis, occurs when the fluoride concentration exceeds 10 mg/L. At this level, the fluoride can cause severe joint pain, bone deformities, and can result in significant disability.

 

Thus, a fluoride concentration of greater than 10 mg/L is associated with the development of crippling fluorosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

â€˜Fluorine is a double edged swordâ€™: Inadequate intake is associated with â€˜dental cariesâ€™ whereas excess intake with â€˜dental and skeletal fluorosisâ€™

 

Crippling fluorosis occurs when fluoride levels in drinking water exceed 10 mg/L, leading to severe and disabling conditions.

questions.text: A 74-year-old male presents to the hospital with urinary hesitancy and retention of urine. An ultrasound reveals an enlarged prostate and a residual urine volume of 130 ml. Which of the following drugs can be used for the treatment of this patient? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5 alpha-reductase inhibitor

 

5 alpha-reductase inhibitors are appropriate for the treatment of urinary symptoms associated with an enlarged prostate (benign prostatic hyperplasia, BPH). These drugs work by shrinking the prostate, thereby relieving urinary symptoms like hesitancy and retention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcium channel blockers: These are primarily used for managing hypertension, not for BPH.

 

Option C. ACE inhibitors: ACE inhibitors are used for treating hypertension and heart failure, not directly for urinary symptoms due to an enlarged prostate.

 

Option D. Aldosterone antagonist: These are used in conditions like heart failure and resistant hypertension, not typically for BPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5 alpha-reductase inhibitors are used to treat urinary symptoms associated with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) by reducing the size of the prostate and relieving urinary hesitancy and retention.

choices.text: 1st trimester USG is the best assessment
Calculated from the last day of the last menstrual period
In an IVF pregnancy, day of embryo transfer/day of fertilization is needed to calculate POG
Crown-rump length is the best measure of period of gestation in the first trimester

questions.text: Identify the wrong statement regarding the period of gestation calculation: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Calculated from the last day of the last menstrual period

 

  • Gestational age or period of gestation (POG) refers to the duration of pregnancy calculated from the first day of last menstrual period
  • Calculating the EDD:
    • Normal duration of pregnancy: 280 days (40 weeks)
    • Calculating the EDD: Naegele’s formula. To the LMP (1st day of the last menstrual day)
      • Add 9 months + 7 days
      • Subtract 3 months and add 7 days
      • For IVF Pregnancies: add 38 weeks to the date of the embryo transfer
    • Dating the pregnancy: If discrepancy in dates/ unsure of LMP; the best way to determine the dating is by ULTRASOUND
      • 1st trimester CRL: most accurate (till 14 weeks)
      • BPD in the 2nd trimester

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1st trimester USG is the best assessment: Correct, because the 1st trimester USG provides the most accurate dating method.

 

Option C. In an IVF pregnancy, day of embryo transfer/day of fertilization is needed to calculate POG: Correct, because calculating gestational age in IVF pregnancies relies on the day of embryo transfer or fertilization.

 

Option D. Crown-rump length is the best measure of period of gestation in the first trimester: Correct, because CRL is the best measure for assessing the period of gestation in the first trimester.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gestational age is calculated from the first day of the last menstrual period (LMP), not the last day.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg, Dutta’s 108, 109, textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg127

questions.text: A young male weighing 46 kg was treated with a drug. It has a Vd of 6 L/kg and clearance of 4.6 L/hour. What is the approximate half-life of this drug? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 40 hours

 

Explanation: 


The half-life can be calculated using the formula:

 
t1/2 = 0.693 Ã— Vd/Clearance

 

  • Vd given is 6 L/kg, so total Vd = 6 Ã— 46 = 276 L
  • Clearance = 4.6 L/hour Therefore: t1/2 = 0.693 Ã— 276/4.6 â‰ˆ 0.693 Ã— 60 â‰ˆ 40 hours


Educational Objective: 


The formula for calculating half-life (t1/2 = 0.693 Ã— Vd/Clearance) and remember to account for total Vd when given in L/kg by multiplying with body weight.

questions.text: Which will you not see in twin pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MADC (Monoamniotic Dichorionic)

 

The correct answer is MADC (Monoamniotic Dichorionic). The classification of twin pregnancies is based on the timing of the zygote's division and the resulting structures, such as the number of chorions (placentas) and amnions (amniotic sacs) that form.

 

  • Dichorionic Diamniotic (DCDA) twins occur when the division happens very early (within the first 72 hours after fertilization), resulting in two separate chorions and amnions.
  • Monochorionic Diamniotic (MCDA) twins occur when the division happens between the 4th and 8th day after fertilization, after the chorion has formed but before the amniotic sac has split.
  • Monochorionic Monoamniotic (MCMA) twins result from division that occurs between the 9th and 12th day after fertilization, after both the chorion and amnion have formed, leading to two embryos sharing a single amniotic sac and a single chorion.
  • Monoamniotic Dichorionic (MADC) is not a possible scenario. The formation of a single amnion with two separate chorions (placentas) does not occur because the chorion forms before the amnion. Thus, this combination is anatomically and developmentally impossible.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. MCMA (Monochorionic Monoamniotic): This is a recognized type of twin pregnancy where twins share both the chorion and the amnion.

 

Option B. MCDA (Monochorionic Diamniotic): Another recognized type, where twins share a chorion but have separate amniotic sacs.

 

Option D. DADC (Dichorionic Diamniotic): This is the most common type of twin pregnancy, especially in dizygotic (fraternal) twins, where each twin has its own chorion and amnion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Monoamniotic Dichorionic (MADC) is not a possible configuration in twin pregnancies. The formation of the amnion and chorion follows a specific sequence that does not allow for this combination. Understanding the timing and resulting structures of zygote division is crucial in determining the type of twin pregnancy.

questions.text: Given the radiograph of a 13-year-old child who presented with fall on elbow. Which of the following bone is fractured? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Humerus

 

  • The image shows fracture of the upper end of humerus.

 

PROXIMAL HUMERUS FRACTURE

 

  • Approximately 40% of metaphyseal proximal humerus fractures are non- or minimally displaced and more commonly require operative treatment as compared to epiphyseal fractures.
  • The peak of these fractures occurs between ages of 10-14 and again at 80-84 years with males more affected.
  • Proximal humerus fractures most often occur upon falling backwards onto an outstretched hand with an extended elbow and externally rotated shoulder or through direct traumatic impact to the shoulder. 
  • The Neer-Horowitz system is the most widely used classification system for proximal humerus fractures in children and is graded by severity of displacement.

 

 

  • On examination, there may be swelling, tenderness, visible deformity, and unwillingness to move the shoulder by holding the arm close to the body.
  • Associated injuries to the brachial plexus, clavicle, and scapula should not be missed.
  • Standard radiographs of the shoulder including AP, and axillary views are generally sufficient to characterize the fracture morphology.
  • The majority of proximal humerus fractures in children can be treated successfully with non-operative management due to the immense remodelling potential of the physis.
  • Neer-Horowitz grade I/II can be successfully treated non-operatively with immobilization in a hanging arm/shoulder spica cast and a sling for 3-4 weeks.
  • Operative treatment should be considered in Neer-Horowitz grade III and IV fractures and greater fracture angulation in older children.
  • Failure of closed reduction should be addressed with open reduction.
  • Fixation options include percutaneous pinning, intramedullary nails, cannulated screws, and plates.

 

 

  • Percutaneous pinning remains the most commonly used fixation strategy.
  • Prognosis in children are generally excellent with both non-operative and operative treatment. 
  • Complications are rare.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clavicle. The clavicle is one of the most common fractured bones in children. These heal quickly and recover fully. Injuries are usually the result of a fall on an outstretched hand with the force transmitted up the arm. A direct blow to the outer end of the clavicle can be associated with distal third injuries and acromioclavicular joint disruption. The vast majority present with pain, swelling and deformity along the line of the clavicle, and a history of a fall onto an outstretched arm. Fractures of the medial third are usually the result of high impact blunt force to the anterior chest (such as in a motor vehicle accident), and can be associated with neurovascular, pulmonary and cardiac (rare) injuries. Careful airway protection and neurovascular assessment is required. Vascular assessment of the arm should also be performed as the subclavian artery runs close to the clavicle in the middle third. Standard AP with 15 degrees cephalic tilt x-ray of the clavicle will show the fracture in two planes and define displacement. The majority of clavicle fractures are easily managed with a sling and analgesia.

 

 

Option C. Scapula. Scapula fractures are uncommon in children. Scapular body fractures are usually the result of high-energy trauma such as motor vehicle collisions or falls. There is a high incidence of associated injuries including other shoulder girdle fractures, rib fractures, head injury, and lung injury, such as pneumothorax or pulmonary contusion. Glenoid fractures are often due to a direct blow to the lateral shoulder or a fall onto a flexed elbow with the humeral head being driven into the glenoid. The position of the arm dictates whether an anterior or posterior rim fracture occurs. Similarly, acromion fractures are usually due to a direct blow to the lateral shoulder. Coracoid fractures are usually an avulsive injury resulting from pull of the acromioclavicular ligaments or the conjoint tendon. Scapulothoracic dissociation is often due to a severe traction injury. The primary symptom is often pain about the shoulder or back and difficulty with motion. Numbness or weakness may be present with a concomitant brachial plexus injury. The majority of fractures are treated non-operatively. Treatment includes immobilization for 3-4 weeks followed by pendulum exercises and protected range of motion. 

 

Option D. Ribs. Rib fracture in children is caused by a high force injury. Ribs 1-3 are the hardest to break. Ribs 4-10 are typically the most vulnerable while ribs 11-12 are more mobile and therefore, more difficult to break. Since children tend to have more elastic ribs than adults, children are less likely to sustain rib fractures. Therefore, children with rib fractures is a sign of significant trauma and should warrant an investigation of possible child abuse. The physical exam may reveal chest wall bruising, along with bony tenderness to palpitation or crepitus. For simple, isolated rib fractures, conservative treatment is usually adequate which includes appropriate analgesia, rest, and ice. The use of an incentive spirometer should be encouraged to prevent pulmonary atelectasis and splinting. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image given in the question shows the fracture of upper end or proximal end of humerus.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis in a smoker patient who presented as shown in the given image and the next investigation required in the management of this patient?  (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Erythroplakia and Biopsy

 

The image shows a red, velvety patch in the oral mucosa of a smoker. This presentation is characteristic of erythroplakia. Erythroplakia is known to have a high risk of malignant transformation, making it a precancerous lesion. Given its potential for developing into oral cancer, the next step in management is to perform a biopsy. A biopsy will allow for histopathological examination to determine the presence of dysplasia or carcinoma, which is critical for guiding further treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Erythroplakia and observation: Observation alone is not appropriate for erythroplakia due to its high risk of malignancy. A biopsy is necessary to assess the lesion.

 

Option C. Leukoplakia and Biopsy: Leukoplakia is characterized by white patches on the mucous membranes, which is not consistent with the red lesion shown in the image.

 

Option D. Leukoplakia and observation: Similar to option C, leukoplakia refers to white patches, and observation alone is not recommended for high-risk lesions without first performing a biopsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythroplakia presents as a red, velvety patch in the oral mucosa and has a high risk of malignant transformation. The appropriate next step in management is to perform a biopsy to determine the presence of dysplasia or carcinoma.

questions.text: Reason of Hepatomegaly in Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Accumulation of glycogen

 

The reason for hepatomegaly (enlarged liver) in this disease is the accumulation of glycogen. Glucose-6-phosphatase is an enzyme involved in gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis. When there is a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase, the normal breakdown of glycogen into glucose is impaired, leading to the accumulation of glycogen within the liver.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Accumulation of Glucose-6-phosphate: While glucose-6-phosphate is an intermediate in glycogenolysis, its accumulation is not the primary cause of hepatomegaly in glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency. Increased Glu-6-P however causes other C/f such as Hyperuricemia, hypertriglyceridemia and Lactic acidosis.

 

Option C. Accumulation of Glucose-1-phosphate: Glucose-1-phosphate is an intermediate in glycogenolysis. It does not accumulate in Von Gierkeâ€™s disease.

 

Option D. Accumulation of glycogenin: Glycogenin is a protein that plays a role in initiating glycogen synthesis, not breakdown. Accumulation of glycogenin is not a typical feature of glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is known as Von Gierkeâ€™s disease or Type I GSD.

choices.text: Head 1/5th palpable per abdomen
Head on perineum

questions.text: Outlet forceps is applied at what station? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Head on perineum

 

Outlet forceps are used when the fetal head is at the outlet of the birth canal, which means the head is visible at the perineum. This typically corresponds to a station of +4 or +5 depending on the system used, but "head on perineum" is the most accurate description.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Head 1/5th palpable per abdomen: This indicates that the head is still relatively high in the birth canal and not at the outlet.

 

Option B. 0 station: This is when the fetal head is at the level of the ischial spines, which is too high for outlet forceps application.

 

Option C. +2 station: This indicates the fetal head is descending but not yet at the perineum. Low forceps might be used at this station, but not outlet forceps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Outlet forceps are applied when the fetal head is visible at the perineum, indicating it is at the outlet of the birth canal.
